summary: Explore the significance of censorship resistance within blockchains, safeguarding transactions from interference or suppression by centralized entities.
post_content:
What is censorship resistance?
The ability of a system, usually a communication or information distribution network, to resist attempts to censor, alter or stop the flow of information is known as censorship resistance. 
Within the realm of digital technology, it frequently alludes to decentralized systems that function without a central authority or control, such as encrypted communication tools, social networking platforms or cryptocurrency systems. These systems ensure the free flow of information even in the face of censorship attempts by spreading control among numerous participants and encrypting conversations.
Systems that are resistant to censorship are essential for maintaining the right to free speech, providing information access in repressive governments, and encouraging creativity by guarding against arbitrary limitations on expression and communication. In the digital age, they are a potent weapon for advancing democracy, human rights and the free flow of ideas.
How censorship affects traditional systems
In traditional systems, censorship weakens the fundamentals of established institutions by preventing free speech, maintaining disparities in power and warping the course of history.
Firstly, it restricts the right to free speech, which is essential to many traditional communities. Ideas stagnate when voices are silenced, impeding advancement both intellectually and culturally. Censorship can impede the transfer of knowledge and values from one generation to the next in traditional systems where oral traditions and storytelling are essential, undermining communal cohesiveness.
Furthermore, censorship frequently perpetuates the power relationships found in established hierarchies. By dictating what information is acceptable, those in positions of power strengthen their hold on the narrative, resulting in the silence of dissident voices, the stifling of critical thought and the maintenance of long-standing disparities.
In addition, censorship has the power to skew historical accounts, reshaping perceptions of the past and collective memory. Governments and other institutions can sway public opinion by restricting access to information, hiding uncomfortable facts and promoting a distorted version of events.
For instance, a kind of censorship occurred in the 2008 financial crisis when risk experts’ warnings about the dangers associated with subprime mortgage-backed securities were played down or disregarded within financial institutions. This lack of transparency about the actual risks partly caused the bubble in the housing market and its subsequent collapse.
Anti-censorship features in blockchain
Several anti-censorship capabilities provided by blockchain technology are crucial for maintaining freedom of speech and the transmission of information. 
It’s crucial to remember that blockchains have limits, even though they have robust anti-censorship capabilities. Governments or other influential organizations may attempt to impose restrictions on network access or even establish more tightly controlled, permissioned blockchains. However, the fundamental structure of blockchains makes them an effective instrument for encouraging free expression and transparent information sharing. 
Anti-censorship features in blockchain include:
Decentralization
Blockchains rely on a dispersed network of computers, or nodes, as opposed to conventional systems that have central authorities. This implies that no single party has complete control over the network, which makes it challenging to remove or filter content.
Immutable ledger
Data entered on the blockchain cannot be removed or changed later. Every link in the chain has a cryptographic hash of the one before it, which prevents manipulation and ensures data integrity. Information censors find it very difficult to influence due to this immutability property.
Transparency
All data and transactions on public blockchains are accessible to all network users. Because of this transparency, attempts at censorship are discouraged because it makes data manipulation obvious.
Encryption
Strong cryptographic techniques are frequently used by blockchains to protect communications and transactions. Because of this encryption, data privacy and integrity are ensured, making it more difficult for censors to intercept or alter data without permission.
The role of consensus mechanisms in censorship resistance
Consensus mechanisms are essential for decentralized systems like blockchain networks to be censorship-resistant.
Without depending on a central authority, these systems allow participants to mutually agree on the veracity of transactions or information. Consensus techniques make it extremely difficult for a single party to filter or modify data by requiring broad agreement across network nodes.
For instance, in proof-of-work (PoW) consensus algorithms, to validate transactions and add them to the blockchain, miners compete to solve challenging cryptography puzzles. Because of the decentralized validation process, censorship is not feasible from an economic or logistical standpoint, as no single entity can control the network.
Similarly, distributed decision-making processes are the foundation of proof-of-stake (PoS) and other consensus methods to achieve censorship resistance. Consensus techniques preserve the ideals of decentralization and censorship resistance by allocating power among network users and rewarding integrity, which promotes trust and security in decentralized systems.
How Bitcoin achieves censorship resistance
Bitcoin’s decentralized consensus mechanism, pseudonymity and decentralized governance allow it to withstand censorship attempts by any centralized authority and maintain the immutability of its transactions.
In the Bitcoin network, miners compete to add transactions to the blockchain and validate them by solving difficult mathematical puzzles. Because the network cannot be controlled by a single party, censorship becomes a challenging endeavor. Any attempt to filter a transaction would have to overwhelm the network’s total processing capacity, which gets more and more difficult as the network grows bigger.
An additional degree of censorship resistance is added by Bitcoin’s pseudonymous nature. Because transactions are broadcast to the whole network and documented on a public ledger, everyone can take part without needing authorization. Any centralized authority would find it difficult to selectively ban transactions based on the sender or content because of this transparency.
Furthermore, Bitcoin’s resistance to censorship is strengthened by its decentralized governance architecture, in which decisions are made by consensus among network users. Modifications to the protocol necessitate wide consensus among participants, making it impervious to censorship efforts by any one person or organization.
Challenges and future of censorship resistance in blockchain technology
Although blockchain technology is inherently immune to censorship, there are still a number of obstacles that need to be overcome to maintain its effectiveness in the face of evolving threats. 
The possible centralization of mining power is a major obstacle that threatens the decentralized nature of blockchain if mining gets concentrated in the hands of a small number of strong entities. Nonetheless, the open nature of most PoW systems means anyone can theoretically join the mining process. This creates competition among miners, making it less likely for a single entity to dominate.
Moreover, censorship resistance faces challenges from legal frameworks and regulatory constraints. Governments may try to control or restrict the use of blockchain technology, which could hinder its capacity to successfully withstand censorship. Adherence to those restrictions may jeopardize the autonomy and decentralization of blockchain networks.
The anonymity and privacy provided by blockchain may be threatened by developments in analysis and monitoring technologies. Maintaining anonymity on public blockchains gets harder as monitoring capabilities advance, putting users at risk of censorship and retaliation.
The future of censorship-resistant blockchains hinges on privacy-enhancing innovations. Technologies like stealth addresses and zero-knowledge proofs offer robust anonymity and resilience against censorship attempts. However, to fully address these obstacles and ensure blockchain’s enduring resistance, continuous research and development are paramount.

summary: The Bank of England and the U.K.’s financial regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority, aim for the inaugural group of applicants to join the Digital Securities Sandbox by autumn 2024.
post_content:
The Bank of England (BoE) and the United Kingdom’s Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) have started a consultation on the draft guidance for their Digital Securities Sandbox (DSS), which is designed to allow participants to test distributed ledger technology (DLT) for trading and settlement of digital securities such as shares and bonds.
According to a joint consultation and draft guidance released on Wednesday, April 3, the sandbox will last five years and could lead to a new regulatory regime for securities settlement.
Successful applicants using the sandbox will be able to provide securities depository and settlement services, as well as operate a trading venue under modified regulations.
The BoE and the FCA aim for the inaugural group of applicants to join the DSS by autumn 2024. FCA Executive Director Sheldon Mills said in a statement:
“The new Digital Securities Sandbox reshapes how we regulate by allowing firms to test regulatory changes using real-world situations before these changes are made permanent. We hope this will be a more effective, collaborative and quicker way of delivering regulatory change.”
The initiative, which is to take place over five years, could pave the way for establishing permanent regulations governing the trading and settlement of digital assets down the line.

The U.K. Treasury first started consultations on the DSS in July 2023. Subsequently, the U.K. government said it would enact legislation to implement the initiative by November 2023.

Following this, the government introduced new regulations in December 2023, offering the nation’s financial regulators guidelines for overseeing the sandbox. These regulations took effect on Jan. 8 as part of the U.K.’s Financial Services and Markets Act 2023.
After releasing the joint consultation paper, interested parties can now provide feedback until May 29. Subsequently, the BOE and FCA will review the feedback and open applications by the summer, with the first applicants joining the initiative by the autumn.
According to the regulators, the DSS will welcome a diverse array of firms, aiming to optimize learning opportunities and foster innovation within the U.K. financial system.
This inclusive approach could facilitate quicker and more cost-effective methods for trading, settling and utilizing securities among financial market participants.

summary: The hacker who once stole over $320 million from the Wormhole bridge appears to have been initially eligible to claim a Wormhole airdrop that would have netted them $50,000.
post_content:
The hacker behind the infamous $320-million exploit of the Wormhole bridge in 2022 was initially deemed eligible for an airdrop that would have seen them claim $50,000 in newly launched W tokens. 
In an April 4 post to X, pseudonymous researcher Pland claimed that the Wormhole team had forgotten to exclude a number of wallet addresses affiliated with an exploit that saw hackers steal $321 million in crypto from the cross-chain bridge in 2022.
According to data from Solana-based airdrop checker Airdrop.link later cited by Degen News in an April 4 post to X, a total of four wallet addresses connected with the exploit were temporarily able to claim Wormhole’s airdrop.
Source: Degen News
If the hacker had elected to claim their airdrops, they would have been eligible for roughly 31,642 Wormhole (W) tokens worth around $50,000 at current prices.

Cointelegraph independently checked the wallet addresses on Airdrop.link; however, we found that they were no longer eligible, suggesting that the Wormhole team may have already plugged the gap.
Cointelegraph contacted Wormhole but did not receive a response by the time of publication.
All four of the eligible wallet addresses were flagged as being linked to the 2022 Wormhole exploit by Solana block explorer Solana.fm.
Related: Wormhole crosses 1B in cross-chain messages ahead of token launch
The Wormhole bridge was exploited for a staggering $321 million in February of 2022, rendering it one of the largest hacks in the history of the crypto industry.
However, in February 2023, Web3 infrastructure firm Jump Crypto and decentralized finance (DeFi) platform Oasis.app conducted a “counter exploit” on the Wormhole protocol hacker.
Source: Spreek
The two firms managed to successfully claw back a total of $225 million in digital assets from the wormhole exploiter and subsequently returned them to safe wallets.
On April 3, Wormhole announced that it would be airdropping more than 675 million — worth roughly $850 million at current prices — of its new Wormhole (W) tokens to eligible users.
